FeedItems.Summary: The NuGet Gallery was unavailable on March 9th from approximately midnight until 7:52 A.M., nearly eight hours. During this time all HTTP requests to the gallery website failed. In addition to...

FeedItems.Title: Introducing the NuGet Team Blog
FeedItems.Summary:
For the last few months, the NuGet team has been considering starting a proper, official blog. This is that blog.

How do we plan to use this blog? Here are a few ways we know we’ll use it (and I’m...

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Validation.Runner may skip packages" (#4207) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
As any job that uses cursor without some additional hardening, it may skip packages as described in #2841.
Monitoring of this job should catch this case though and the chances of this happening are pretty slim, so no huge deal, but process could definitely be improved here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deprecate the ability to copy 'Full access API keys'" (#5231) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Discussion issue for the [NuGet/Announcement#16](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/16):

**Starting Feb 5th 2018, the 'Full access API key' cannot be copied from NuGet.org**. While most of the packages pushed to NuGet.org now use a scoped API key and are not impacted by this change, users continuing to use our legacy 'Full access API keys' will need to securely stash the key before this date after which they will not be accessible. Please note that the 'Full access API keys' will continue to work just like they did before. We are only removing the ability to copy them down from NuGet.org.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Site admins should be able to modify organization membership" (#5557) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Consider we receive the following support request. The admin of a company's organization has left the company and no longer has access to their account.

In order to resolve this, site admins may need the ability to add modify the organization's membership manually. This is, however, not possible currently.

For this reason, site admins should be given this ability.

This is analogous to admins being able to modify package ownership.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet Server] Unable to restore (some) Semver 2.0 versioned packages" (#5528) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary

It is not possible to restore some packages with a valid Semver 2.0 version from NuGet.Server. For instance, the package version `1.2.3-a1234-2` works fine, but the version `1.2.3-a1234.2` does not.

The second example is valid Semver 2.0 as per https://semver.org/

## Symptoms

* The package version *does not* show up in the XML served at `nugetserver/nuget/Packages`
* The package version *does not* show up in the XML served by `nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='MyPackage'`
* From the CLI, attempting to restore the package using `dotnet restore` results in the output below
* Inside Visual Studio, when managing NuGet packages, the version *does* show as available but selecting it and clicking *Update* also results in the output shown below

```
error NU1102: Unable to find package MyPackage with version (>= 1.2.3-a1234.2)
error NU1102:   - Found 99 version(s) in my-repo [ Nearest version: 1.2.0 ]
error NU1102:   - Found 1 version(s) in nuget.org [ Nearest version: 1.0.0 ]
error NU1102:   - Found 0 version(s) in local-artifacts
``` 

## Reproducing

```bash
mkdir net-core-nuget-lib
cd net-core-nuget-lib/
dotnet new classlib
dotnet build
dotnet pack -c release /p:Version=1.2.3-a1234.2
dotnet pack -c release /p:Version=1.2.3-a1234-2
dotnet nuget push ./bin/release/net-core-nuget-lib.1.2.3-a1234.2.nupkg --source http://myrepo.example.com/api/v2/package --api-key my-api-key
dotnet nuget push ./bin/release/net-core-nuget-lib.1.2.3-a1234-2.nupkg --source http://myrepo.example.com/api/v2/package --api-key my-api-key
curl 'http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id=%27net-core-nuget-lib%27'
```

The output from cURL above includes version `1.2.3-a1234-2` but *not* `1.2.3-a1234.2`:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices" xmlns:m="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/metadata" xml:base="http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/">
  <id>http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/FindPackagesById</id>
  <title type="text">FindPackagesById</title>
  <updated>2018-02-21T23:03:15Z</updated>
  <link rel="self" title="FindPackagesById" href="FindPackagesById"/>
  <entry>
    <id>http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/nuget/Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')</id>
    <category term="NuGet.Server.DataServices.ODataPackage" scheme="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/scheme"/>
    <link rel="edit" title="ODataPackage" href="Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')"/>
    <title type="text">net-core-nuget-lib</title>
    <summary type="text"/>
    <published>2018-02-21T22:59:26Z</published>
    <updated>2018-02-21T22:59:26Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>net-core-nuget-lib</name>
    </author>
    <link rel="edit-media" title="ODataPackage" href="Packages(Id='net-core-nuget-lib',Version='1.2.3-a1234-2')/$value"/>
    <content type="application/zip" src="http://myrepo.example.com/nugetserver/api/v2/package/net-core-nuget-lib/1.2.3-a1234-2"/>
    <m:properties>
      <d:Version>1.2.3-a1234-2</d:Version>
      <d:NormalizedVersion>1.2.3-a1234-2</d:NormalizedVersion>
      <d:IsPrerelease m:type="Edm.Boolean">true</d:IsPrerelease>
      <d:Title m:null="true"/>
      <d:Owners>net-core-nuget-lib</d:Owners>
      <d:IconUrl m:null="true"/>
      <d:LicenseUrl m:null="true"/>
      <d:ProjectUrl m:null="true"/>
      <d:DownloadCount m:type="Edm.Int32">-1</d:DownloadCount>
      <d:RequireLicenseAcceptance m:type="Edm.Boolean">false</d:RequireLicenseAcceptance>
      <d:DevelopmentDependency m:type="Edm.Boolean">false</d:DevelopmentDependency>
      <d:Description>Package Description</d:Description>
      <d:Summary m:null="true"/>
      <d:ReleaseNotes m:null="true"/>
      <d:Published m:type="Edm.DateTime">2018-02-21T22:59:26.8807552Z</d:Published>
      <d:Dependencies>::netstandard2.0</d:Dependencies>
      <d:PackageHash>EwclxIGcCHkNeKJ875v4OWLiU5hkhnc8PosCre4JfCauFkF9qDazbd31sUhZy6PyR0aOzSuvMbOAEUXErFKXdg==</d:PackageHash>
      <d:PackageHashAlgorithm>SHA512</d:PackageHashAlgorithm>
      <d:PackageSize m:type="Edm.Int64">3287</d:PackageSize>
      <d:Copyright m:null="true"/>
      <d:Tags m:null="true"/>
      <d:IsAbsoluteLatestVersion m:type="Edm.Boolean">true</d:IsAbsoluteLatestVersion>
      <d:IsLatestVersion m:type="Edm.Boolean">false</d:IsLatestVersion>
      <d:Listed m:type="Edm.Boolean">true</d:Listed>
      <d:VersionDownloadCount m:type="Edm.Int32">-1</d:VersionDownloadCount>
      <d:MinClientVersion m:null="true"/>
      <d:Language m:null="true"/>
    </m:properties>
  </entry>
</feed>
```

## Environment

This issue was reproduced using NuGet.Server **2.14.2**.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Orchestrator] Delay the delivery of validation requests" (#5529) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Upon receiving a package's validation request, the Orchestrator polls the Gallery database once a minute until it finds the package that should be validated. Unfortunately, the Orchestrator often receives the validation request seconds before the Gallery has had a chance to persist changes to its database. In other words, the Orchestrator often waits a full minute to validate a package, when in reality, it should have only waited a few seconds.

This change aims to drastically reduce the time the Orchestrator waits to start a package's validation by delaying the delivery of the validation request by 5 seconds.

Tracked by https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1179
Will be followed by https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1180

## Supporting Data

I ran the following Application Insights query:

```
traces
| where message contains "Starting Enqueuing asynchronous package validation"
| join (requests | where name == "POST Packages/VerifyPackage" or name == "PUT Api/PushPackageApi" | project requestTimestamp = timestamp, duration, operation_Id) on operation_Id 
| project requestTimestamp, validationTimestamp = timestamp, duration
| extend timeToEnqueue = ((validationTimestamp - requestTimestamp)/ time(1ms))
| extend timeAfterEnqueue = duration - timeToEnqueue
| summarize percentiles(timeAfterEnqueue, 10, 50, 75, 80, 90, 95, 99), max(timeAfterEnqueue)
```

This `timeAfterEnqueue` estimates the the time upload requests spent after the validation request has been enqueued to persist changes to the database (it also includes the package upload to blob storage). The breakdown for `timeAfterEnqueue` for ALL requests (including failed ones) since December 1st is:

10% | 50% | 75% | 80% | 90% | 95% | 99%
--- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | ---
2s | 3s | 3.7s | 4s | 10.3s | 12.4s | 38.6s

This shows that by delaying the delivery of validation requests by 5 seconds, at least 80% of validation requests will begin after waiting 5 seconds.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[MSA/AAD] Make list of email domains required to discontinue password login configurable via file" (#5386) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The list of email domains required to discontinue password login should be configurable via a file and should support not just email domains but individual email addresses as well.

This should likely be done in JSON with an inclusion and exclusion list.

This should likely be separate from the list of users that organizations supports.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageReference projects cannot find SemVer 2.0.0 packages " (#6625) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It looks there are two `FindPackagesById` code paths:

Incorrect:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/9f5c5b0a93eff691e3300605418b620f6c7991fc/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/RemoteRepositories/RemoteV2FindPackageByIdResource.cs#L345

Correct:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/9f5c5b0a93eff691e3300605418b620f6c7991fc/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/LegacyFeed/V2FeedQueryBuilder.cs#L36

packages.config projects don't seem to be effected.

Tested dev branch, 4.3.0, 4.5.1. All have the same issue. I think we shipped SemVer 2.0.0 protocol support with this bug.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "<packageSourceCredentials> ignored when feed defined in higher config" (#3580) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Related to #3568 but slightly different as it works the other way around. Tested with NuGet 3.5.0-beta2/.NET CLI 1.0.1.
## Steps
1. Put a `<packageSource>` with `<packageSourceCredentials>` in a NuGet.Config at **application** level, next to project.json.
2. Add a `<clear />` to the `<packageSources>`. Config looks like:

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="NuGet" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="vsts" value="{some VSTS feed}" />
  </packageSources>
  <packageSourceCredentials>
    <VSTS>
      <add key="Username" value="vsts" />
      <add key="ClearTextPassword" value="blah" />
    </VSTS>
  </packageSourceCredentials>
</configuration>
```
1. Add the same feed to a "higher" NuGet.Config, e.g. the one in `%APPDATA%/NuGet/NuGet.Config`.
2. Call `dotnet restore` on a project.json with a package in the VSTS feed.
## Expected

A clearer error message _or_ that NuGet ignores the feeds configured in  `%APPDATA%/NuGet/NuGet.Config` as `<clear />` was added to a "lower" config and adds an Authorization header to the request.
## Actual

NuGet does not add the Authorization header and the call fails with:

```
λ dotnet restore
log  : Restoring packages for C:\src\ConsoleApp8\src\ConsoleApp8\project.json...
error: Unable to load the service index for source {the feed}/nuget/v3/index.json.
error:   An error occurred while sending the request.
error:   The parameter is incorrect
```

I can see with Fiddler that NuGet sends a bunch of requests to the VSTS with, all without a Authorization header which obviously fails with an HTTP 401.

/cc @tkrick

Related to #3568 but slightly different as it works the other way around. Tested with NuGet 3.5.0-beta2/.NET CLI 1.0.1.
## Steps

    <VSTS>
      <add key="Username" value="vsts" />

    </VSTS>

</configuration>
```
1. Add the same feed to a "higher" NuGet.Config, e.g. the one in `%APPDATA%/NuGet/NuGet.Config`.
2. Call `dotnet restore` on a project.json with a package in the VSTS feed.
## Expected

## Actual

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Extra files and ProjectReference" (#6624) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Consider removing the extensibility that allows other package managers to be shown as compatible" (#6623) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Create any PR/PJ based project and open the PM UI and see that there's a
```
Incompatible: Use Bower instead
```
when we list those packages. 

This is achieved with an extensibility point that allows other "alternative" managers to talk to NuGet and advertise if they're the preferred option for those packages.
Code [here.](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Models/AlternativePackageManagerProviders.cs)

The reason why these packages are incompatible is because they contain content, the mutable v2 kind. 
However, if you read the [ASP.NET](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/client-side/bower) docs, there's conflicting information.

These 2 packages are perfect examples of what contentFiles should be used for. 

We should consider removing this "AlternativePackageManagerProviders" goo, and work with the jquery/bootstrap nuget package maintainers to make these 2 packages PR compatible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Added Informative Shields" (#6622) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Retrieve list of all packages from private feed with V3 API" (#6480) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Our team is moving from V2 feeds to V3 feeds hosted in VSO, and I have been tasked with updating some of our build-time tooling that does sanity checks on the packages in the private feeds.

In V2 it was fairly trivial to get a complete listing of package IDs in a gallery and then drill into versions and specific package metadata.  Having read through the available documentation on using the API directly (which appears to be rather sparse at the moment) and reviewed existing bugs/issues/enhancements that appear recent and related (eg, #6393 ), it seems what I'm looking for is a Catalog resource in the feed.

It would appear that VSO NuGet feeds don't supply this resource, as I cannot locate any index entries with `@type` containing `Catalog`.  Is the Catalog resource the only practical means for getting a complete package listing from V3 feeds?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget Restore does not work with pre-release Versions" (#6580) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create Nuget feed with only pre-release versions
2. Create Project (.csproj) with reference to nuget package using floating version i.e. <PackageReference Include="[package name]" Version="3.*" />
3. Perform Nuget CLI Restore as part of build process using Nuget feed

## Error Received
Unable to find a stable package [package name] with version (>= 3.0.0)

It seems that Nuget CLI Restore cannot handle pre-release versions which is a rather large short coming.

## Suggestion
Add  -IncludePrerelease flag

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Wrong app.config file is updated on package install" (#6476) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When using MSBuild's `<AppConfig>` property to change the default app/web.config path on a given project, nuget.exe will completely ignore this property and try to generate a new app/web.config file whenever configuration changes are needed (like binding redirects).

This behavior is clearly incorrect. This `AppConfig` property is part of the algorithm used by MSBuild to find a project's configuration file and should be taken into account by nuget.exe as well.

Some information about the MSBuild logic and support for `AppConfig`:
https://timvw.be/2008/03/17/easily-switching-between-appconfig-files-with-msbuild/

I tried attaching a zipped project here but Github simply refuses to accept it (tried zipping a solution and then an isolated project). Adding even a PNG is not working, so let me know if you need extra information here and how I can provide it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecation of www.nuget.org/nuget.exe" (#20) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5381|

We are deprecating the use of URL: **www.nuget.org/nuget.exe** which currently downloads nuget.exe version 2.8.6. If you have a dependency on this URL, we recommend you to start using **https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v2.8.6/nuget.exe**. 

For consistency, we are also changing this endpoint to redirect to dist.nuget.org, which is our primary home for downloading all released versions of nuget.exe. 

**Old redirect:** https://az320820.vo.msecnd.net/downloads/nuget.exe 
**New redirect:** https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v2.8.6/nuget.exe

If you are interested in downloading newer versions of nuget.exe, please see the [Downloads](https://www.nuget.org/downloads) page on nuget.org.

For other methods of installing our client tools, please see our [Installing NuGet client tool](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/install-nuget-client-tools) documentation.

**Note:** There is no immediate plan to remove the URL **www.nuget.org/nuget.exe** . We will monitor the usage before taking it offline. We will also reach out again before taking the URL offline.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating the ability to copy Full access API keys" (#16) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|*None*|[NuGet/NuGetGallery#5231](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231)|

We on the NuGet.org team are committed to continually seek ways to improve the security of our services. A year ago, we introduced [scoped API keys](https://blog.nuget.org/20170202/introducing-scoped-api-keys.html) to help our users better manage their API keys. While we recommend the use of scoped API keys, we will continue to support our legacy 'Full access API keys' that were previously granted by the service. Such keys do not expire if you use them at least one every 365 days to push a package.
 
We are making a change to our service such that a newly issued API key cannot be copied after the page is refreshed. While this was always the case for scoped API keys, we were allowing users with 'Full access API keys' to copy them down at any point. We plan to remove this capability in the future, as making this change allows us to migrate all of our APIs keys to use a one-way hash and further protect against malicious use of the key.

**Starting Feb 5th 2018, the 'Full access API key' cannot be copied from NuGet.org**. While most of the packages pushed to NuGet.org now use a scoped API key and are not impacted by this change, users continuing to use our legacy 'Full access API keys' will need to securely stash the key before this date after which they will not be accessible. Please note that the 'Full access API keys' will continue to work just like they did before. We are only removing the ability to copy them down from NuGet.org.

If you have further question, please reach out to us by commenting on the [discussion issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231) or send me an email at [anangaur@microsoft.com](mailto:anangaur@microsoft.com).
